verses.text: There is an evil which I have seen under the sun, and it \add is\add* common among men:

a man to whom God hath given riches, wealth, and honour, so that he wanteth nothing for his soul of all that he desireth, yet God giveth him not power to eat thereof, but a stranger eateth it: this \add is\add* vanity, and it \add is\add* an evil disease.

If a man beget an hundred \add children\add*, and live many years, so that the days of his years be many, and his soul be not filled with good, and also \add that\add* he have no burial; I say, \add that\add* an untimely birth \add is\add* better than he.
For he cometh in with vanity, and departeth in darkness, and his name shall be covered with darkness.
Moreover he hath not seen the sun, nor known \add any thing:\add* this hath more rest than the other.
Yea, though he live a thousand years twice \add told\add*, yet hath he seen no good: do not all go to one place?
All the labour of man \add is\add* for his mouth, and yet the appetite is not filled.
For what hath the wise more than the fool? what hath the poor, that knoweth to walk before the living?
Better \add is\add* the sight of the eyes than the wandering of the desire: this \add is\add* also vanity and vexation of spirit.
That which hath been is named already, and \add it is\add* known that it \add is\add* man: neither may he contend with him that \add is\add* mightier than he.
Seeing there be many things that increase vanity, what \add is\add* man the better?
For who knoweth what \add is\add* good for man in \add this\add* life, all the days of his vain life which he spendeth as a shadow? for who can tell a man what shall be after him under the sun?
